NewsLine.NewsLineText: MIDEAST-HIGHLIGHTS 1330 GMT:Reuters Middle East Highlights 1330 GMT Sept 23

body.p: LONDON - Britain said a draft U.N. Security Council resolution on Iraq would be tabled within days and would make it clear to Saddam Hussein that he must honour previous commitments and disarm.

COPENHAGEN - EU president Denmark said 25 Asian and European Union leaders at a summit agreed that Iraq must re-admit arms inspectors as speedily as possible and allow them full and free access to its facilities.
RAMALLAH, West Bank - Israeli and Palestinian officials held their first talks since the army imposed a siege on Yasser Arafat's West Bank headquarters, but failed to end the four-day-old standoff.

After the talks, the Israeli army briefly opened its tight security cordon around Arafat's devastated presidential complex in Ramallah to let chief Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat in to brief the Palestinian leader on the meeting.

RAMALLAH, West Bank - Palestinian President Yasser Arafat rejected Israeli demands to present a list naming all the people holed up with him in his West Bank headquarters, a senior Palestinian official said.
ANKARA - Turkish Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit renewed his invitation to Israelis and Palestinians to meet for peace talks in Turkey, saying he feared escalating violence.

TEHRAN - Iran said it had accepted London's nomination of a new British ambassador, ending a seven-month diplomatic dispute following Tehran's rejection of Britain's former candidate for the job earlier this year. The new appointee was not named.
BAGHDAD - Iraq denounced as "wicked" U.S. attempts at the United Nations to adopt a tough resolution on Iraq's disarmament, saying Washington was seeking U.N. cover for any military action.
DAMASCUS - Syria called on the United Nations to rein in Israel and its military action against Palestinians, saying that conflict deserved as much attention as the global body is giving to Iraq.
BAGHDAD - Iraq's Foreign Minister Naji Sabri left Baghdad to deliver a message from President Saddam Hussein to Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak in Cairo, the official Iraqi News Agency said.
BEIRUT - A small bomb ripped through the parking lot of a McDonald's restaurant in an eastern suburb of Beirut, damaging cars but causing no injuries, court sources said.

ATHENS - The United Nations special envoy for Cyprus said a settlement on the divided island was still possible before the European Union decides in December if Nicosia will be admitted among the first wave of new members.

ATHENS - Greece, which takes over the EU presidency at the end of the year, welcomed the election win of Germany's Social Democrats saying it boded well for Turkey's hopes of joining the European Union.

CAIRO - A mysterious door has been found in a previously unexplored shaft inside Egypt's biggest pyramid, only days after a similar stone slab was found in another shaft, antiquities chief Zahi Hawass said.
